answers.explanation: This intra-retinal, hyperreflective lesion most likely represents a hard exudate. Drusen is usually located underneath the RPE and not within the retina. On the other hand, cotton wool spots are usually located within the nerve fiber layer as they represent focal infarction of the axons in this layer. CNVM is not typically associated with NPDR and is usually seen as a small hyperreflective growth emerging from the choroid into the retina.

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text:
Given the clinical history, what does the hyper-fluorescent lesion in the OCT photo (left) likely represent?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text: Which layer are hard exudates usually located in:

answers.explanation: Hard exudates are mainly located in the outer plexiform and inner plexiform layers. Remember that hard exudates consist of lipid residue due to serous leakage from damage capillaries, and thus deposit in the areas where edema are typically located.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text:
What other additional features are present in the OCT photo:

![](/content/media/retina-31-1.webp)

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina-31-4.webp)

A microaneurysm (yellow arrow) is found adjacent to the hard exudate. It is characterized by a hyper-reflective ring around an area of hypo-reflectivity. The black area underneath the hard exudate represents shadowing effect and not RPE loss.

answers.answerText: B. Loss of RPE underneath the hyper-reflective lesion

questions.title: Question 4

answers.explanation:
Clinically Significant Macular Edema - Early Treatment for Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS):

1. Retinal thickening located at or within 500 µm of the center of the macula
2. Hard exudates located at or within 500 µm of the center of the macula and associated with adjacent retinal thickening
3. Area of retinal thickening more than 1 disc area located within 1 disc diameter from the center of the macula

questions.title: Question 5
questions.text: What is the differential diagnosis for lesions that can lead to hard exudate?

answers.explanation:
Any condition that lead to vascular leakage can lead to a hard exudate. Some examples are below:

1. DM

2. HTN

3. CNVM

4. Capillary hemangioma

5. Retinal microaneurysm

6. Coat’s disease

title: Case 31
description: 57M presenting with a history of diabetes mellitus
patientPresentation: A 57-year-old male diagnosed with diabetes mellitus (DM) presented to clinic for a routine eye exam. His vision was 20/25 OD and 20/30 OS. His intraocular pressures were normal, and his slit lamp exam was unremarkable. Dilated fundus exam showed moderate non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR).
